sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि | यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्चितम् ||1||
transliteration:
arjuna uvācha
sannyāsaṁ karmaṇāṁ kṛiṣhṇa punar yogaṁ cha śhaṁsasi
yac chreya etayor ekaṁ tan me brūhi suniśhchitam
translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, You praise renunciation of actions and also selfless action. Please tell me decisively which of the two is more beneficial.

sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ | तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते ||2||
transliteration:
śhrī-bhagavān uvācha
sannyāsaḥ karma-yogaśh cha niḥśhreyasa-karāv ubhau
tayos tu karma-sannyāsāt karma-yogo viśhiṣhyate
translation: The Blessed Lord said: Both renunciation of action and selfless action lead to liberation. But of the two, selfless action is superior.

sanskrit: ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति | निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते ||3||
transliteration:
jñeyaḥ sa nitya-sannyāsī yo na dveṣhṭi na kāṅkṣhati
nirdvandvo hi mahā-bāho sukhaṁ bandhāt pramuchyate
translation: One who neither hates nor desires is known as a true renunciant. Such a person, free from dualities, is easily liberated from bondage.

sanskrit: साङ्ख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः | एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम् ||4||
transliteration:
sāṅkhya-yogau pṛithag bālāḥ pravadanti na paṇḍitāḥ
ekam apy āsthitaḥ samyag ubhayor vindate phalam
translation: Only the ignorant speak of the path of knowledge and the path of selfless action as different. The wise see them as one and the same.

sanskrit: यत्साङ्ख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते | एकं साङ्ख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति ||5||
transliteration:
yat sāṅkhyaiḥ prāpyate sthānaṁ tad yogair api gamyate
ekaṁ sāṅkhyaṁ cha yogaṁ cha yaḥ paśhyati sa paśhyati
translation: The state attained by the path of knowledge is also attained by the path of selfless action. One who sees both paths as leading to the same goal truly sees.

sanskrit: संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः | योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति ||6||
transliteration:
sannyāsas tu mahā-bāho duḥkham āptum ayogataḥ
yoga-yukto munir brahma na chireṇādhigachchhati
translation: Renunciation without selfless action leads to misery, O mighty-armed Arjuna. But the sage who is harmonized through yoga quickly attains Brahman.

sanskrit: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः | सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते ||7||
transliteration:
yoga-yukto viśhuddhātmā vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ
sarva-bhūtātma-bhūtātmā kurvann api na lipyate
translation: One who is devoted to the path of selfless action, whose mind and senses are controlled, and who sees the Self in all beings, is not bound by actions.

sanskrit: नैव किंचित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित् | पश्यञ्शृण्वन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपंश्वसन् ||8||
transliteration:
naiva kiñchit karomīti yukto manyeta tattva-vit
paśhyañ śhṛiṇvan spṛiśhan jighrann aśhnan gachchan svapan śhvasan
translation: The truly wise, engaged in selfless action, think 'I do nothing at all,' even while seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, moving, sleeping, or breathing.

sanskrit: प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि | इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन् ||9||
transliteration:
pralapan visṛijan gṛihṇan unmiṣhan nimiṣhann api
indriyāṇīndriyārtheṣhu vartanta iti dhārayan
translation: While talking, giving, taking, opening or closing the eyes, the wise understand that it is only the senses acting upon their objects.

sanskrit: ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः | लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा ||10||
transliteration:
brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ
lipyate na sa pāpena padma-patram ivāmbhasā
translation: One who performs actions without attachment, offering them to Brahman, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus leaf remains untouched by water.

sanskrit: कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि | योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वात्मशुद्धये ||11||
transliteration:
kāyena manasā buddhyā kevalair indriyair api
yoginaḥ karma kurvanti saṅgaṁ tyaktvātma-śhuddhaye
translation: Yogis perform actions with the body, mind, intellect, and senses, without attachment, for the purpose of self-purification.

sanskrit: युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम् | अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते ||12||
transliteration:
yuktaḥ karma-phalaṁ tyaktvā śhāntim āpnoti naiṣhṭhikīm
ayuktaḥ kāma-kāreṇa phale sakto nibadhyate
translation: The self-controlled, who performs actions without attachment, attains perfect peace. But the one who is attached to the fruits of work becomes entangled.

sanskrit: सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी | नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन् ||13||
transliteration:
sarva-karmāṇi manasā sannyasyāste sukhaṁ vaśhī
nava-dvāre pure dehī naiva kurvan na kārayan
translation: Mentally renouncing all actions, the self-controlled soul resides happily in the city of nine gates (the body), neither acting nor causing action.

sanskrit: न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः | न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते ||14||
transliteration:
na kartṛitvaṁ na karmāṇi lokasya sṛijati prabhuḥ
na karma-phala-saṅyogaṁ svabhāvas tu pravartate
translation: The Supreme does not create agency, actions, or the union with the fruits of action. All this is enacted by the modes of material nature.

sanskrit: नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः | अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः ||15||
transliteration:
nādatte kasyachit pāpaṁ na chaiva sukṛitaṁ vibhuḥ
ajñānenāvṛitaṁ jñānaṁ tena muhyanti jantavaḥ
translation: The Supreme Being does not accept anyone’s sinful or virtuous deeds. Knowledge is covered by ignorance, and thus living beings are deluded.

sanskrit: ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः | तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् ||16||
transliteration:
jñānena tu tad ajñānaṁ yeṣhāṁ nāśhitam ātmanaḥ
teṣhām āditya-vaj jñānaṁ prakāśhayati tat param
translation: But for those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge, the knowledge reveals the Supreme like the sun illuminates everything.

sanskrit: तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः | गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः ||17||
transliteration:
tad-buddhayas tad-ātmānas tan-niṣṭhās tat-parāyaṇāḥ
gachchhanty apunar-āvṛittiṁ jñāna-nirdhūta-kalmaṣhāḥ
translation: Those whose minds are absorbed in the Supreme, who are steadfast and devoted, and whose sins are destroyed by knowledge, attain liberation and do not return to this world.

sanskrit: विद्याविनयसम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि | शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः ||18||
transliteration:
vidyā-vinaya-sampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini
śhuni chaiva śhva-pāke cha paṇḍitāḥ sama-darśhinaḥ
translation: The wise see with equal vision a learned and humble Brahmin, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and a dog-eater.

sanskrit: इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः | निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः ||19||
transliteration:
ihaiva tair jitaḥ sargo yeṣhāṁ sāmye sthitaṁ manaḥ
nirdoṣhaṁ hi samaṁ brahma tasmād brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ
translation: Those whose minds are established in equality have conquered the cycle of birth and death. They are flawless like Brahman and are situated in Brahman.

sanskrit: न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम् | स्थिरबुद्धिरसम्मूढो ब्रह्मविद्ब्रह्मणि स्थितः ||20||
transliteration:
na prahṛiṣyet priyaṁ prāpya nodvijet prāpya chāpriyam
sthira-buddhir asammūḍho brahma-vid brahmaṇi sthitaḥ
translation: One who is not elated by pleasant experiences or disturbed by unpleasant ones, who is steady and unconfused, is truly situated in Brahman.

sanskrit: बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम् | स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते ||21||
transliteration:
bāhya-sparśheṣhv asaktātmā vindaty ātmani yat sukham
sa brahma-yoga-yuktātmā sukham akṣhayam aśhnute
translation: One who is unattached to external pleasures and finds joy in the Self, such a person, united with Brahman, enjoys eternal bliss.

sanskrit: ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते | आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः ||22||
transliteration:
ye hi saṁsparśa-jā bhogā duḥkha-yonaya eva te
ādy-antavantaḥ kaunteya na teṣhu ramate budhaḥ
translation: Pleasures that arise from contact with the senses are sources of misery. They have a beginning and an end, O Kaunteya, and the wise do not delight in them.

sanskrit: शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात् | कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः ||23||
transliteration:
śaknotīhaiva yaḥ soḍhuṁ prāk śharīra-vimokṣhaṇāt
kāma-krodhodbhavaṁ vegaṁ sa yuktaḥ sa sukhī naraḥ
translation: One who is able to resist the impulses of desire and anger before giving up the body is a yogi and a happy person.

sanskrit: योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तरारामस्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः | स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति ||24||
transliteration:
yo ’ntaḥ-sukho ’ntar-ārāmas tathāntar-jyotir eva yaḥ
sa yogī brahma-nirvāṇaṁ brahma-bhūto ’dhigachchhati
translation: One who finds happiness within, who is active within, and who rejoices within, is a true yogi and attains liberation in Brahman.

sanskrit: लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः | छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः ||25||
transliteration:
labhante brahma-nirvāṇam ṛiṣhayaḥ kṣhīṇa-kalmaṣhāḥ
chhinna-dvaidhā yatātmānaḥ sarva-bhūta-hite ratāḥ
translation: Sages who are free from sin, whose doubts are destroyed, who are self-controlled and engaged in the welfare of all beings, attain liberation in Brahman.

sanskrit: कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम् | अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम् ||26||
transliteration:
kāma-krodha-viyuktānāṁ yatīnāṁ yata-chetasām
abhito brahma-nirvāṇaṁ vartate viditātmanām
translation: Those who are free from desire and anger, who are self-controlled and have realized the Self, attain liberation in Brahman on all sides.

sanskrit: स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः | प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ ||27||
transliteration:
sparśhān kṛitvā bahir bāhyāṁśh chakṣhuśh chaivāntare bhruvoḥ
prāṇāpānau samau kṛitvā nāsābhyantara-chāriṇau
translation: Shutting out all external contacts and fixing the gaze between the eyebrows, equalizing the inward and outward breaths moving within the nostrils...

sanskrit: यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः | विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः ||28||
transliteration:
yatendriya-mano-buddhir munir mokṣha-parāyaṇaḥ
vigata-ichchhā-bhaya-krodho yaḥ sadā mukta eva saḥ
translation: Having controlled the senses, mind, and intellect, the sage who is intent on liberation, free from desire, fear, and anger, is ever liberated.

sanskrit: भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम् | सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति ||29||
transliteration:
bhoktāraṁ yajña-tapasāṁ sarva-loka-maheśhvaram
su-hṛidaṁ sarva-bhūtānāṁ jñātvā māṁ śhāntim ṛichchhati
translation: Knowing Me as the enjoyer of all sacrifices and austerities, the Supreme Lord of all worlds, and the friend of all beings, one attains peace.
